titleStmt.title: Consistency of interval fuzzy preference relations in group decision making

affiliation.orgName: PLA University of Science and Technology

analytic.title: Consistency of interval fuzzy preference relations in group decision making

biblStruct.note: Received 12 January 2009 Received in revised form 5 October 2009 Accepted 17 January 2011

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Group decision making Interval fuzzy preference relation Quadratic programming model Numerical analysis

div.p: Interval fuzzy preference relations are an extension of fuzzy preference relations, which are usually used by experts to express their uncertain preference information over objects in group decision making. In this paper, we focus our attention on the investigation of consistency of interval fuzzy preference relations. We first establish a quadratic programming model by minimizing all the deviations of individual interval fuzzy preference relations and collective interval fuzzy preference relation, from which an exact solution can be found to derive the importance weights of experts. Then, we give two approaches to constructing additive and multiplicative consistent interval fuzzy preference relations, respectively, and show the relationship between the consistency of individual interval fuzzy preference relations and the consistency of collective interval fuzzy preference relation. At last, a practical application is given to our models and approaches.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Interval fuzzy preference relations are a useful tool to describe experts' preferences over objects in group decision making under uncertainty, where the experts have vague knowledge about the preference degree of one object over another, and cannot estimate their preferences with exact numerical values, but with interval numbers [1,5]. The concept of interval fuzzy preference relation was introduced by Xu [17], and based on interval fuzzy preference relation, a priority method was given to determine the weights of objects, and a possibility degree formula was used to rank and select the given objects. Some authors investigated similarity measures, aggregation and priority methods of interval fuzzy preference relations, for example, Xu [18] defined the concept of compatibility degree of two interval fuzzy preference relations, and showed the compatibility relationship among individual interval fuzzy preference relations and collective interval fuzzy preference relation. Herrera et al. [4] developed an aggregation process for combining interval fuzzy preference relations with other types of information such as numerical preference relation and linguistic preference relation. Xu and Chen [19,21] systematically investigated multiple attribute group decision making problems with different formats of preference information (including: (1) interval utility values [11,13]; (2) interval fuzzy preference relations [17,18]; and (3) interval multiplicative preference relations [3,12,15,16,23], etc.) on attributes and alternatives respectively, and established a series of linear or goal programming decision making models integrating the given objective information and all structures of subjective uncertain preference information. The established model not only can reflect both the subjective considerations of all experts and the objective information but also can avoid losing and distorting the given objective and subjective decision information in the process of information integration. Jiang [6] gave an index to measure the similarity degree of two interval fuzzy preference relations, and used the error-propagation principle to determine the priority vector of the aggregated interval fuzzy preference relations. On the basis of a convex combination method, Lan and Liu [8] transformed an interval fuzzy preference relation into a traditional fuzzy preference relation [2,7,9,10,14] from which a priority method was derived for ranking the given objects. Recently, Xu and Chen [22] defined some new concepts such as additive consistent interval fuzzy preference relation, multiplicative consistent interval fuzzy preference relation, and based on which they established some linear programming models for deriving the priority weights from various interval fuzzy preference relations.

Nevertheless, in the process of decision making, it is very difficult for an expert to construct a consistent interval fuzzy preference relation, due to the influence of the limited ability of human thinking, and thus, in order to derive a scientific and reasonable decision result, it is needful to improve the consistency of interval fuzzy preference relations. The objective of this paper is to solve this issue, and we organize the rest of the paper as follows. Section 2 establishes a quadratic programming model by minimizing all the deviations of individual interval fuzzy preference relations and collective interval fuzzy preference relation, the exact solution to which can be derived to determine the importance weights of experts. In Section 3, we give an approach to constructing additive consistent interval fuzzy preference relation. In Section 4, we give an approach to constructing multiplicative consistent interval fuzzy preference relation. Section 5 gives a practical example to illustrate our models and approaches, and at last we end the paper with some concluding remarks in Section 6.

div.head: A quadratic programming model for determining the weights of experts
div.p: In the real life situations, a decision is usually made by a group of the experts e k (k = 1, 2, . . ., m), whose weight vector = ( 1 , 2 , . . ., m ) T is to be determined. These experts provide their preferences over a collection of the objects x i (i = 1, 2, . . ., n), and the preferences are expressed in interval numbers instead of exact numerical values because of complexity and uncertainty of the considered problems or the limited ability of human thinking. That is, each expert e k compares each pair of the objects x i (i = 1, 2, . . ., n), and constructs an interval fuzzy preference relation Ãk = (ã

div.head: Practical example
div.p: In the following, we apply our models and approaches to a military problem that concerns group decision making under uncertainty.

Fire system is a dynamic system achieved by collocating and allocating various firearms involved in an appropriate way. The fire system of a tank unit is an essential part when the commander tries to execute fire distribution in a defensive combat. The fire deployment is of great importance in fulfilling a fixed goal, improving the defensive stability, annihilating enemies, and protecting ourselves. The third company of our tank unit is organizing a defensive battle in Xiaoshan region, and many factors may impact the selection of fire system proposals [20]. The following is the list of five critical factors: (1) x 1 -concealment by making use of the landforms; (2) x 2 -reduction of the mobility of enemy airplanes; (3) x 3 -combination with obstacles; (4) x 4 -cooperation with mutual firepower; (5) x 5 -air-defense capacity. A committee comprising of three experts e k (k = 1, 2, 3) has been set up to provide assessment information on x i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5). The experts e k (k = 1, 2, 3) compare each pair of the factors x i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) (here both the weight vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , w 3 , w 4 , w 5 ) T of the factors and the weight vector = ( 1 , 2 , 3 ) T of the experts are to be determined) and construct the interval fuzzy preference relations 2, 3, 4, 5) of the objects x i (i = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) from the angles of maximizing, respectively, the additive consistency and the multiplicative consistency of all Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3), and the rankings of the weights derived from the models (M-3) and (M-7) are slightly different, due to that the model (M-7) is a nonlinear goal programming model and thus, the solution to the model (M-7) may be locally optimal, which is subject to the original weight vector.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: The consistency of interval fuzzy preference relations and the weights of experts play an important role in reaching a reasonable decision result for group decision making with interval fuzzy preference relations. In this paper, from the viewpoint of minimizing all the deviations of individual interval fuzzy preference relations and collective interval fuzzy preference relation, we have first established a quadratic programming model to derive the weights of experts, and shown that the optimal solution to our model can be derived by a simple and straightforward formula. Then, on the basis of each individual interval fuzzy preference relation, we have established two goal programming models to check the additive and multiplicative consistency of the individual interval fuzzy preference relation, respectively. Based on the optimization deviation values and the original interval fuzzy preference relations, we have given an approach to constructing additive or multiplicative consistent interval fuzzy preference relations. Furthermore, we have established two goal programming models integrating all individual interval fuzzy preference relations to derive the weights and the ranking of the given objects from the angles of maximizing, respectively, the additive consistency and the multiplicative consistency of all individual interval fuzzy preference relations, and also shown the relationship between the consistency of individual interval fuzzy preference relations and the consistency of collective interval fuzzy preference relation. The developed models and approaches can be used in many practical applications, such as group evaluation processes, and information retrieval, etc., and also can be extended to group decision making with intuitionistic fuzzy information.

By using the model (M-2) and (21), we can improve any an interval fuzzy preference relation into an additive consistent interval fuzzy preference relation. In the model (M-2), we only consider an individual interval fuzzy preference relation Ãk = (ã (k) ij ) n×n . div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The author is very grateful to the anonymous referees for their constructive comments and suggestions that have led to an improved version of this paper. The work was supported by the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars of China (No. 70625005), and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 71071161).
Considering that the weight vector of the experts is unavailable, Xu [18] utilized the uncertain averaging operator:
, for all i, j = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5
to aggregate all Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3) into the collective interval fuzzy preference relation Ã = (ã ij ) 5×5 ãij = [a - ij , a + ij ], i, j = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 :

Then by the uncertain normalizing rank aggregation method [17]: wi = Clearly, the approach above can aggregate all individual opinions into group one, and can also derive uncertain priorities from an interval fuzzy preference relation. But the approach has the following drawbacks:
(1) It cannot determine the importance weights of the experts in group decision making.
(2) It can only get the weight intervals but cannot derive the optimal weights of the factors from all individual interval fuzzy preference relations.

(3) It cannot check and improve the consistency of interval fuzzy preference relations. However, we can use the models and approaches developed in this paper to overcome these issues. In the following, we shall give a detailed numerical analysis to illustrate the developed models and approaches.

Based on Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3), we first utilize the model (M-1) (or ( 14)) to derive the weight vector = (1/3, 1/3, 1/3) T of the experts e k (k = 1, 2, 3). Then, we check the consistency of all Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3) by solving the models (M-2), (M-3), (M-6) and (M-7), respectively, i.e.,
(1) By (M-2), we get optimal objective values ˙J(1)

Since the model (M-2) only considers each one of the individual interval fuzzy preference relations. In order to derive the weight vector of the objects, we need to consider all the individual interval fuzzy preference relations as a whole, and thus, we further solve the model (M-3), and get the optimal objective value ˙J1 = 4.8, and the optimal deviation values:

Since ˙J1 / = 0, then the solutions to the model (M-3) are the optimal weights: w 1 = 0.335, w 2 = 0.235, w 3 = 0.161, w 4 = 0.035, w 5 = 0.234, and then w 1 > w 2 > w 5 > w 3 > w 4 , which indicates x 1 x 2 x 5 x 3 x 4 , where " " means "is superior to". Thus, x 1 is the best factor. In addition, from the optimal deviation values derived by the model (M-3), it follows that all Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3) are not additive consistent, and therefore, based on the optimal deviation values ḋ-(k) ij and ḋ+(k) ij (i, j = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, k = 1, 2, 3), we utilize (21) to improve Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3) into the corresponding additive consistent interval fuzzy preference relations:

we utilize (21) to improve Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3) into the corresponding multiplicative consistent interval fuzzy preference relations: From the above numerical results, we know all Ãk (k = 1, 2, 3) are neither additive consistent nor multiplicative. Consequently, by using the models (M-2), (M-3), (M-6) and (M-7), we have improved these interval fuzzy preference relations into the corresponding additive or multiplicative consistent interval fuzzy preference relations. In particular, from the models (M-3) and (M-7), we get the weights w i (i = 1,
